screen_name: BirgitC

@miriam_vollmer Ja, bin ca 60% ok, Atemprobleme etc pp. Mein Mann hatte schlimmen Relapse am WE mit hohem Fieber & noch immer gastro Probleme. Wir sind aber nicht allein, Tausende von uns: https://t.co/sBDrlmFv1w

#covid19ESP   #covid1in20 #apresJ20 #apresJ60 #MitCoronaLeben  #CovidPersistente

@thesuingone Herzrasen, Fieber fuer 4 und dann nochmal 2 Wochen, Puls 140, hoher Blutdruck (fuer mich) 160/100, dann Atmung schwer, Brennen in der Lunge, extremes Stechen in den Rippen, Kreuzschmerzen, Schmerzen in der Schulter, Druck auf den Zaehnen, Geschmacks- & Geruchssinn verzerrt (2)

@sabinedoering @Marius_Raabe Danke!!  Bitte nicht auf die leichte Schulter nehmen und ganz vorsichtig sein.  Symptome variieren sehr je nach Person, aber ich hatte ueber 3 Wochen lang Fieber und konnte teils kaum aus dem Bett kriechen (keine Uebertreibung, leider).

@katemeredithp @StarredBastard @WHO @cdc Nor is the @NHSuk who are still telling us about fever and continuous cough. @BorisJohnson  is clearly not on top of things in the UK either. He looks rather unwell and I wonder about the neurological effects Covid has had / is having on him.  Road to nowhere...

@katemeredithp Hmm, likely. My husband is working (remotely but fully) & had several very long days last week where he worked 15h or so. Then the relapse with tightness in chest, heart beat racing, fatigue, high fever, GI. Fever down, GI issues massive. It's relentless. I send you MUCH LOVE!!

@katemeredithp Oh Kate. My husband had the same last week and then had awful GI symptoms with high fever for the last three days. Husband and I are both on day 72 of Covid (recovery). Sending you much, much love.

Husband having a #covid relapse with high fever & bad GI symptoms. 

7 year old son just said: "It seems like all the happiness has been sucked out of the world".  

I have SOB, dizziness myself, headache, close to breaking down in tears.  Day 70 with Covid.

"As more information becomes available, the {UK] government’s Covid model seems increasingly out of date. Many Covid patients do not develop a fever and cough. Instead they get muscle ache, a sore throat and headache. "  Yes, agree. I never really coughed much.
@LawyerKostya The official NHS information is not helping... makes no sense. Fever and cough, over after 7 days. Sure, as long as we all stay alert...  I am bracing myself for the second wave.

@hsmall @atheist_punk1 Hearing such drivel really upsets me. I have never been so ill in my whole life, I'm breathless, dizzy, have fever etc on day 55 of this awful virus. "Supernatural"? I cannot believe someone talking like that is an official advisor to anyone. Awful.

@robsmith115 @ElenaBrowett @FernRiddell At the peak of the virus, middle 18 days, I could feel it like electricity or evil bees under my skin moving up and down my whole body, that combined with the fever and dizziness.  I was so weak at some point, I was crawling. Just crazy.  Is it the neural system, you think?
@lilianedwards ... sinus pain at the beginning, aches and cramps, raised temp and fever on and off, massive exhaustion, no cough but trying to clear throat all the time, headache...?

@katemeredithp Hmm, likely. My husband is working (remotely but fully) & had several very long days last week where he worked 15h or so. Then the relapse with tightness in chest, heart beat racing, fatigue, high fever, GI. Fever down, GI issues massive. It's relentless. I send you MUCH LOVE!!

@katemeredithp Oh Kate. My husband had the same last week and then had awful GI symptoms with high fever for the last three days. Husband and I are both on day 72 of Covid (recovery). Sending you much, much love.

Husband having a #covid relapse with high fever & bad GI symptoms. 

7 year old son just said: "It seems like all the happiness has been sucked out of the world".  

I have SOB, dizziness myself, headache, close to breaking down in tears.  Day 70 with Covid.

@preshitorian @BorisJohnson Yes, hit & miss with NHS GPs. Private ones seem to know everything (have access through my work). One NHS GP told me that GI symptoms are not Covid, only(!) continuous cough and fever. I told him I was reading the Lancet & he then connected me to local Covid hub, that GP was good

@DrAlexConcorde Similarly, German official list of Covid symptoms differs strongly from NHS info - but why?: cough (50% of patients), fever( 41%), cold (21%), pneumonia (2.9%) & sore throat, shortness of breath, headache & body aches, no appetite, weight loss, nausea, abdominal pain, (1/2)

@AlexAnstey She is actually very good - I shouldn't kill the messenger. I already had awful continuous dry cough end of Jan/Feb this year where my lungs felt like I had swallowed talcum powder and no this thing - day 37.   Just so exhausted by being unwell ...

@robsmith115 @ElenaBrowett @FernRiddell My friends spoke to a private French GP, who recommended it. I felt it kept the cough I wanted to start at bay and made me breath more easily. My lung function improved too. Shower (and smell of shower gel I usually love) also made me feel like suffocating.  So I can relate!

@robsmith115 @ElenaBrowett @FernRiddell Had no cough but had to clear my throat constantly, throat hurt, fever, aches, taste/smell funny, GI issues, sinuses pain. Only when I read German info & heard friends who had been in contact with French GP did I realise that 40% have no cough. Lungs hurt though & brainfog, dizzy
@lorelixenberg The first thing in Jan/Feb was a cold & cough I think, what I have (had) now is Covid.

@lorelixenberg Thank you Lore. It's a new disease, I understand that. Had this weird, endless tickly dry cough at end Jan/Feb after having been in the lift with a Chinese delegation where my lungs felt tight & I ended up with breathing problems after 2 weeks. My lungs feel similar now. Oh dear.
@lilianedwards ... sinus pain at the beginning, aches and cramps, raised temp and fever on and off, massive exhaustion, no cough but trying to clear throat all the time, headache...?

@miafia @M_Wilson_FL @kealchambers @peterjukes @OxfordDiplomat Let's hope we are now all finally recovering.  I just don't think we will be immune.  I had a lingering cold with awful barking cough already from 24 Jan to mid Feb where I had breathing problems too (& had been in a lift with Chinese delegation at my office on 21 Jan).

@ClaireHastie1 @DominicMoss13 @RTF0D3N @j4mesrenfrew @preshitorian @manx_maid @PaulGarnerWoof Same to you Claire.  Husband so far had no GI or lung stabbing pain symptoms, he has got them now, all new. I had them for much longer. So hard to stay positive, it's so scary at times #covid1in20
@manx_maid @DominicMoss13 My kind Covid GP suggested I have that.  Backpain, stabbing pain ribs, tight chest.  Joys (huh) of Covid.
@MaksA90514125 I got the sharp burning pain in my ribcage to the left, lower end of my rips, side and front.
@lancebloke83 @hughesthenews I have chest and back pain too.

@juliettet83 @LtotheJtotheP I had 10 really good days in between with just some breathlessness and pain in my lungs and it then came back with a vengeance. Please take it easy, don't rush back to work and sending you a hug. 1940s music is a great idea.  x

@Jodie11957620 A slight burning sensation on my chest, on my skin, not so much on my face but buzzing & fizzing through my whole body.  I also had "ad chest pain and squeezing round chest and rib cage and short of breath as well as not eating". Lost over 10kg since 16 March. Get better!! Hug.

@EdwardSmith11 40 days plus and another flare up. Tonight's #covid symptoms: breathing is not great, have stabbing pain in my lungs, feeling very weak and a bit of a temperature again.  Weird pain in my left arm.
@lilianedwards ... sinus pain at the beginning, aches and cramps, raised temp and fever on and off, massive exhaustion, no cough but trying to clear throat all the time, headache...?
@CatherineMcEnr1 @Ellemarie_318 I had a sore throat again too, around day 63.  My husband now has a tight chest, around day 64 onwards.  It's crazy.

@DrAlexConcorde Similarly, German official list of Covid symptoms differs strongly from NHS info - but why?: cough (50% of patients), fever( 41%), cold (21%), pneumonia (2.9%) & sore throat, shortness of breath, headache & body aches, no appetite, weight loss, nausea, abdominal pain, (1/2)

"As more information becomes available, the {UK] government’s Covid model seems increasingly out of date. Many Covid patients do not develop a fever and cough. Instead they get muscle ache, a sore throat and headache. "  Yes, agree. I never really coughed much.

"Calling the UK’s recent decision to add anosmia - loss of smell -  to the official Covid-19 symptoms list “long overdue”, Prof Spector adds that breathlessness and fevers are also recurring symptoms in patients struggling with the “long tail” form of the virus."  Yes, like me.
"Revealed: the long-term severe effects of Covid-19 that could go on for months" yes, mine started on 16 March 2020 and are still ongoing (oh and how I wish they weren't!) https://t.co/ReED48Iedu

'Weird as hell’: the Covid-19 patients who have symptoms for months: "According to the latest research, about one in 20 Covid patients experience long-term on-off symptoms. It’s unclear whether long-term means two months, or three or longer." https://t.co/Z1i4XZEkfs
Another realistic article about the reality of #Covid. "What It's Like To Have COVID-19 Symptoms For Nearly 2 Months"  https://t.co/UYvunxCnUm

The fiendish complexity of Covid-19 "Our evolving experience with Covid-19 raises the spectre of a minority of patients suffering long-term effects... may also occur in some patients whose initial illness did not warrant hospitalisation" https://t.co/q4SUPs6h3V
For a growing number of COVID-19 patients, symptoms last more than a month. Four young patients who've been sick 30-plus days say they're 'terrified.' https://t.co/kuTVBRpi81
Germany's Covid-19 expert: 'For many, I'm the evil guy crippling the economy' https://t.co/RfLJ95rwGr

Via @skrumskrum - this is really helpful advice for everyone else in my TL recovering from #Covid.   
And all those who telling me, "surely you can't still feel unwell": "Ongoing symptoms could last for several months after you contract COVID-19 and this can be perfectly normal." https://t.co/1GGoMz46Dj

"Another question that could take years to answer is whether the SARS-CoV-2 virus that causes COVID-19 may lie dormant in the body for years and spring back later in different form."   https://t.co/9nfjCbesdg

@BendlerBlogger @RA_Boehme @PreislerKa Dr Randy Jacobs, an assistant clinical professor of dermatology at the University of California, said COVID-19 can ‘feature signs of small blood vessel occlusion’ – clotting of the blood  – according to The Hospitalist.

https://t.co/T6i4KzHFfM
@sabinedoering @nypost COVID-19 may leave a patient's lungs, heart, kidneys and brain changed https://t.co/8yw3QsZRYO 😳

"Calling the UK’s recent decision to add anosmia - loss of smell -  to the official Covid-19 symptoms list “long overdue”, Prof Spector adds that breathlessness and fevers are also recurring symptoms in patients struggling with the “long tail” form of the virus."  Yes, like me.

@robsmith115 @ElenaBrowett @FernRiddell My friends spoke to a private French GP, who recommended it. I felt it kept the cough I wanted to start at bay and made me breath more easily. My lung function improved too. Shower (and smell of shower gel I usually love) also made me feel like suffocating.  So I can relate!

@robsmith115 @ElenaBrowett @FernRiddell My symptoms started on 16/3.  Sense of smell distorted, having to work harder to breath properly, headache, dizzy, so tired so quickly. Still get echoes of the buzzing/fizzing under my skin too.  Wishing everyone a full recovery!  It feels like an endless battle.

@felicitycallard "Suspected" since UK won't test, started 16/3 as mild cold, sinus issues, 23/3 onwards 18 days of being very unwell, since then slowly getting better day by day but not recovered.  Prickly lungs, sense of smell distorted, tired, dizzy, headaches, etc.  I am "ok" but not well.

@MeganMolteni @WIRED Dizziness, confusion and distorted sense of smell, for a while it was heightened.  I still get (mild) headaches and the dizziness. Sense of smell slowly going back to normal.  I was so spaced out my 7yr old son told me "Mummy you make no sense!". Hope this goes away in time.
@skrumskrum @miafia I have a distorted and oddly heightened sense of smell and taste.  My wheat allergy is flaring up like crazy too. It's just an endless battle.

"...others have described "#dysosmia"—when you go to smell something and it smells like something...else. Something unpleasant." via @jackholmes0 #covid

https://t.co/ypRjb7C4VI

@JolyonMaugham @GoodLawProject Can you raise awareness about something? People stopping bon fires for the time being. In self isolation feeling v poorly, people in our road have had a bon fire on all day despite being asked not to. @wealdendistrict @Wealden_Police
can't help! Smoke smell really bad for lungs.

"Calling the UK’s recent decision to add anosmia - loss of smell -  to the official Covid-19 symptoms list “long overdue”, Prof Spector adds that breathlessness and fevers are also recurring symptoms in patients struggling with the “long tail” form of the virus."  Yes, like me.

@LeighTurnerFCO @PeterRNeumann @sebastianborger There are so many reports now about Covid being transmitted through the eyes. Wearing (sun) glasses makes perfect sense and also to keep them on whilst on the tube/underground. Otherwise you may touch your face without meaning to. Day 63 of Covid for me. https://t.co/gqgaIarSSH

@Jlarlat1 Hi, thanks for checking; similar to @miafia @skrumskrum I had a very bad relapse and absolutely horrific GI symptoms, fever, headache. Touch and go whether I need to be in hospital on Monday/Tuesday.  Am more stable now, but so weak. Sending much love. It's day 49 I think.

@DrAlexConcorde vomiting, diarrhea, conjunctivitis, rash, swelling of the lymph nodes, apathy, somnolence, see here:
https://t.co/8dKrK1Xxf8.

@AlexAnstey @Ellemarie_318 @BeccaSews Our 7 year old didn't want to finish his lunch and had cold hands, my husband (usually as calm as they come): please can you take his temperature? 7 yr old: Are you crazy?  I am fine, I just don't like the food.

My pulse was racing when I took his temperature, which was normal.
@miafia @esofiagood I had this on my weird new red patches on my leg and the inside of my arms today.  Feeling cold is a good description but it's a slightly different feeling.
@lorelixenberg The first thing in Jan/Feb was a cold & cough I think, what I have (had) now is Covid.

@miafia @M_Wilson_FL @kealchambers @peterjukes @OxfordDiplomat I can relate.  I think I was already weak from the cold in Jan/Feb and I cannot cope with getting this again either.  I was so weak at times that even getting out of bed felt like climbing a mountain.  If it hadn't been for our son, I don't know.  It drains you completely.

@miafia @M_Wilson_FL @kealchambers @peterjukes @OxfordDiplomat Let's hope we are now all finally recovering.  I just don't think we will be immune.  I had a lingering cold with awful barking cough already from 24 Jan to mid Feb where I had breathing problems too (& had been in a lift with Chinese delegation at my office on 21 Jan).

@DominicMoss13 @manx_maid I didn't realise I had lost weight. My husband told me I looked thin. I actually felt really big and bloated (snap!) and thought that scales had a fault.  I was initially quite hungry, then lack of appetite (week 3?), and the relapse: no appetite.  It is very strange.

"As more information becomes available, the {UK] government’s Covid model seems increasingly out of date. Many Covid patients do not develop a fever and cough. Instead they get muscle ache, a sore throat and headache. "  Yes, agree. I never really coughed much.
@angie_roo2 @lagresti I know what you mean, I really, really do. Not sure it's a consolation.  I am so tired of it all too. Sending you a hug, Angie.
@angie_roo2 How is your blood pressure?  I am tired too but then can't sleep when I want...

@m1shef @jwdaddy80 I did, not so great today.  You aren't quite right either, I can tell, same goes for Justin.  Sending you both all my best wishes. It's such a rollercoaster still. So sick and tired of it. x

@jwdaddy80 I fear it's a political decision not to tell people about this.  I wonder how many years this has taken off my life expectancy. I am worried I have lung damage.  I tired quickly and feel dizzy half of the day and have headaches.  Awful.

@jwdaddy80 @lagresti Same in our family, it's just so difficult. My husband also still has lingering covid symptoms (both day 55) & we are both tired & unwell. I started comparing UK healthsystem with Germany's yesterday & had a massive rant about UK government failing us. Husband was quite shocked.

@robsmith115 @ElenaBrowett @FernRiddell My symptoms started on 16/3.  Sense of smell distorted, having to work harder to breath properly, headache, dizzy, so tired so quickly. Still get echoes of the buzzing/fizzing under my skin too.  Wishing everyone a full recovery!  It feels like an endless battle.
@twitsrus1 @miafia @grishund It's great news.  Feeling really tired after having worked another full day...
@skrumskrum @ProfSteinkogler @miafia He is very tired and gets a bit out of breath a bit too quickly. We are better than we were, definitely but it goes up and down a bit even now.

@lilianedwards @c_drosten The person who most likely gave it us didn't even realise they had it, they were tired for a week and exhausted with headache and then had high temp, bad aches for 3 days and were "ok" again.  We were a lot more ill than they were, I even more than my husband. So, not sure...

@miafia @memap4 @peterjukes @OxfordDiplomat Day 28 for me today.  Haven't had that but still have gritty eyes, echos of the tingling now in my hips (weird), headaches and feel like I need to take a deep breath every now and then, hoarse voice and soooo tired and weak.

@AMinhall @ClassicFM Well deserved! I'm new to your show too since I can now *also* listen to @ClassicFM during the day while working from home. Thank you for brightening our afternoon as we slowly recover from Covid. Brahms Rhapsody Op. 79, No. 1 would be a nice piece to play for everyone.

"For English law governed contracts, this will require consideration of the force majeure clause (if any) contained in the contract as well as business continuity / disaster recover obligations." https://t.co/CJeh7oi6e9

@BoormanPatrick @Fox4HailshamNT Sadly, you cannot rely upon common sense as seen in London today.  I agree with your views in principle but seeing how ill I have been with Covid and still cannot shake it off 58 days in, I think masks need to be compulsory.

@hughesthenews If you need another person to interview who has been ill for weeks including relapse, etc. I am also in the UK.  It's day 54 for me. I can't shake it off either. There are more of us than is reported.  Shouldn't the official NHS guidelines be updated?

@FJojiana @readheadreader Day 58 for me, Mollie. You're not alone, a lot of us have ever changing symptoms. Mentally prepare yourself to take every day at a time. Be careful with Vit C, when I had my relapse, I had colitis and Vit C made it worse. Info & support groups list here: https://t.co/J3fQOVLWB6

@manx_maid @DominicMoss13 I am taking no medication. I take Vit D and Zinc und drink lots of water. Off Vit C after the awful colitis. I wear warm PJs now.... all day.  Have lost 10 kg since 16 March. Bah! Have you tried drinking peppermint tea (it seems to do something for me)

@DominicMoss13 @manx_maid Have lost over 10kg since 16 March. So pleased now that I had put on so much weight over Christmas and winter. I only had the GI symptoms with the relapse.  Also have a metallic taste in my mouth.

Any #allergy sufferers out there experiencing a worsening of their allergies during (and post) #covid?

I did not experience #anosmia but rather something more like #dysosmia... just a distorted sense of taste and smell, rather than a lack of it.  Anyone else?

@mikeirons12 @Lord_Steerforth @ljfrsa @DrDavidVernon @TimAshAsh @marciehughes @DumleKogbara @LeahBroad @StaffeldtAnke @deeplyclassical @hairygit @ARBurtonWorld @Jud1960 @aquilanebula @chiotchiot1 @BeckeMika @sjohnh @WinstonMei1967 @rmkinnunen @wolweichs @ElizAthertonSop @steinbck Indeed.  Again, my taste for melancholic and bittersweet "kitsch" coming through again.  Love it.

@manx_maid @DominicMoss13 I am taking no medication. I take Vit D and Zinc und drink lots of water. Off Vit C after the awful colitis. I wear warm PJs now.... all day.  Have lost 10 kg since 16 March. Bah! Have you tried drinking peppermint tea (it seems to do something for me)

@m1shef @jwdaddy80 blood brain barrier.... don't even want to google that, even though I have an inkling what it means.  I am always tired.  My temp is up a bit today (oh dear), sat 98/99 and blood pressure 106/56 (better than it was) - feeling a bit breathless. Pulse 75. Day 57.

@jwdaddy80 My husband's symptoms started on the same day as mine, 16 March. We have been battling this together, flare ups and all.  We think our 7 year old son also had it. When he exerts himself, he now starts coughing. He also had the red eyes, was off his food, grumpy and tires quickly.

@ElenaBrowett @robsmith115 @FernRiddell Us too. Son had milder symptoms (we also all had red eyes), runny nose for half a day and was grouchy, sleepy etc. Husband was milder than me but still pretty bad. Son seems ok, husband better than me. Hope we will all be well again soonest (and no long term issues please).

@BeccaSews @Ellemarie_318 @AlexAnstey Our son had red eyes, was grouchy, weepy and felt very hot when I was at the peak of virus. He also had one day with a slightly runny nose, just before our weak symptoms started, so chances are he had it too. That said, I seem to be unable to react rationally.

@skrumskrum @ProfSteinkogler @miafia Day 35; husband & I started symptoms same day. They weren't identical, his temp was lower, he didn't have the awful fizzing eg, but our ups and downs were at same time, red burny eye, dizziness & headaches. Unsure about 7yr old son, he was grouchy, sleepy, red eyes - nightmare.

@miafia @M_Wilson_FL @kealchambers @peterjukes @OxfordDiplomat My 7 year old son (still not sure whether he had it but he had very red eyes and grouchy) said to me: Mummy, you realise you make no sense?  He started looking after himself, shower, cloths, etc and husband (also symptom) and I only put food outside his door.   Surreal times.

@jwdaddy80 My husband's symptoms started on the same day as mine, 16 March. We have been battling this together, flare ups and all.  We think our 7 year old son also had it. When he exerts himself, he now starts coughing. He also had the red eyes, was off his food, grumpy and tires quickly.

@jwdaddy80 My husband enjoys running and it's his favourite hobby.  Today he was out of breath having to climb the stairs to the first floor in our house twice carrying lego our 7 year old left downstairs.  It's crazy.  I get you completely.  A lot more needs to be published about this.
